medical_history.chief_complaint: Decompensated cirrhosis due to primary hepatitis C virus infection in HIV-infected men.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began with elevated liver transaminases detected during routine laboratory testing, progressing to jaundice, tan-colored stools, and eventually decompensated cirrhosis within 17 months to 6 years after primary hepatitis C infection. Factors that aggravated symptoms included low CD4 counts and continued HIV infection. Treatment interruptions and lack of effective hepatitis C treatment were also noted.
medical_history.past_medical_history: History of AIDS in three of the four men, with significant immunocompromise attributed to HIV infection.
medical_history.social_history: History of unprotected receptive anal intercourse with multiple partners. Some individuals reported alcohol use and drug use, including methamphetamine, which may have contributed to liver damage.
